subSubSection.paragraph: Liogma fuscipennis in Alexander 1932 111-112: original description; Alexander 1953a : 55-56, syn. nov.

Violovich leg.; ZIN.

Head. Black with weak greyish pubescence (Fig. 28C, D ). Rostrum short without nasus, but with few hairs (Fig. 28B, E ); rostrum and mouthparts brown to black (Fig. 28B, E ). Palpus brown to black, five-segmented; first two segments sometimes darker than the rest; last segment 1.3-1.8 x longer than penultimate. Scape cylindrical 1.5-2 x longer than pedicel (Fig. 4F ); pedicel ovate; pedicel and scape same coloured or scape slightly darker, yellowish brown to brown; flagellum 14 segmented, monochrome dark brown to black; flagellar segments greatly expanded ventrally in male, last flagellomere cylindrical (Figs 4F , 28D ). Flagellomeres 2-6 or 7 extended in female, remaining segments cylindrical (Figs 4F , 28E ). Extended flagellomeres covered with dense whitish sensilla; 2-4 long verticels on dorsal surface, two verticels in lateral surface, two shorter on ventral side; first flagellomere always bearing additional verticels (Fig. 4F ).

subSubSection.paragraph: Abdomen. Black, without any clear patterns (Fig. 28A ).

(Alexander, 1913). Red dots indicate locations of investigated specimens, white dots indicate approximate locations of literature data.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The morphological comparison of this species with
L. brevipecten
is discussed under that species. Colouration is variable within specimens of
Liogma serraticornis
. Usually, colouration is black with a paler pleural area, and the wing membrane is almost transparent, tinged with pale yellowish brown. In darker specimens, the pleural area and wing membrane is infuscated. This darker form was described as a separate species,
Liogma fuscipennis
Alexander, 1932, but was later synonymised with
L. serraticornis
(Alexander 1953). No genital and genetic difference between the paler and darker specimens were found during our study.
